awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2018 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Anna Romanov "Geometric Representation Theory". The host institution for the fellowship is University of Sydney, NSW, Australia and the sponsoring scientist is Geordie Williamson.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
From 2018-2021, Dr. Anna Romanov completed mathematics research at the University of Sydney, supported by an NSF Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowship. Dr. Romanov's research was focused on understanding the representation theory of Lie groups, which are mathematical objects that describe symmetry which varies continuously. Such symmetry occurs naturally in the physical world (for example, within the elementary particles which make up our universe), and by providing a mathematical description of this symmetry using representation theory, researchers can better understand the effects of such symmetry on the physical systems displaying it.

Dr. Romanov was specifically studying a type of representations called Whittaker modules. A fundamental question about any class of representations is how they are built; that is, what are the most basic representations (the "building blocks"), and how those basic representations combine to form all representations. During her tenure in Sydney, Dr. Romanov answered this fundamental question for Whittaker modules by providing a geometric algorithm to compute the composition series of standard Whittaker modules. By answering this question geometrically, she developed a geometric approach to studying this class of representations, providing access to powerful tools in algebraic geometry which could then be used to address other open questions about Whittaker modules.

Dr. Romanov followed up this work, which was published in 2021 in as the article "A Kazhdan-Lusztig algorithm for Whittaker modules" in the journal Algebras and Representation Theory, with a more in-depth description of an additional structure carried by standard Whittaker modules - the structure of contravariant forms. With her collaborator Dr. Adam Brown (Institute for Science and Technology Austria), she showed that in contrast to other well-studied classes of representations, standard Whittaker modules admit multiple dimensions of contravariant forms. This result showed that Whittaker modules behave distinctly to their classical cousins Verma modules, and it initiated a departure from the traditional methods which had previously been used to study representations of Lie algebras. These new methods allowed Dr. Romanov and Dr. Brown to prove several more results about Whittaker modules, including an algebraic construction of a new class of costandard Whittaker modules, a proof that the category of Whittaker modules carries a highest weight structure, and a description of projective multiplicities in the category. Some of this work was published in Proceedings of the American Mathematical Society in the 2020 article "Contravariant forms on Whittaker modules", and the rest of it is contained in the article "Highest weight structures on Whittaker categories", which is currently under review.

While based at Sydney, Dr. Romanov frequently travelled internationally to speak about this work at conferences. At one such conference, the Representation Theory XVI conference in Dubrovnik, Croatia, she was invited as a plenary speaker, and discussions after her talk led her to write the article "Four examples of Beilinson-Bernstein localization", which was published in 2020 in the AMS Contemporary Mathematics volume which emerged from the conference. She was also invited to speak on this work in Austria, Germany, Hong Kong, Canada, and across the United States and Australia. These talks initiated several related research projects on which she is currently working and established mathematical connections between the University of Sydney and the global representation theory community.

In addition to the intellectual contributions made by her research on Whittaker modules, Dr. Romanov participated in several outreach events during her tenure as an NSF Postdoctoral Fellow. In 2018, she spoke in Raising the Bar Sydney, an international event involving free public lectures by academic researchers in popular public spaces. In her talk, which was made into a podcast, she described the discoveries of two revolutionary 19th century female mathematicians who were early pioneers of representation theory. By interweaving mathematical ideas with the life stories of these unlikely heroes, she introduced the audience to new role models who do not appear in history books, potentially shifting their notions about who does mathematics. In addition to this public lecture, she gave presentations to high school students about careers in mathematics, worked with undergraduate students on research projects, and was involved in an interdisciplinary collaboration in which she worked with R&B artist Mi-Kaisha to create an original piece of music based on Dr. Romanov's mathematics research. By bringing mathematics into spaces where it is not usually found, Dr. Romanov's work through her NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship made broad impacts in education and science outreach.
